answers.answer: Terrance,Q:"Does high levels cause afib?"Not directly.  But atherosclerotic disease is commonly associated with afib, and atherosclerotic disease is also commonly associated with hypercholesterolemia.Q:"Have ever known of any cases where a significant drop in cholesterol levels has caused afib to go away?"No.  But afib is associated with elevations in CRP.  Statin therapy drops CRP, so it is possible, but unproven, that statin therapy may decrease propensity for developing or maintaining afib.Q:"Is the protocol of prescribing coumadin for men over 65 and a baby aspirin for men under 65 still being used?"Most practitioners prescribe coumadin for patients over the age of 65 with afib.  Patients under 65 need consideration for coumadin based on other risk factors for stroke, like heart failure, previous stroke, diabetes, plus others.Hope that helps.
